snp2.12:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Āḷavī, at Āḷavī’s premier shrine.
snp2.12:1.3: Now at that time it was not long after Venerable Vaṅgīsa’s mentor, the senior monk named Nigrodhakappa, had become fully quenched.
snp2.12:1.4: Then as Vaṅgīsa was in private retreat this thought came to his mind:
snp2.12:1.5: “Has my mentor become quenched or not?”
snp2.12:1.6: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Vaṅgīsa came out of retreat and went to the Buddha. He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
snp2.12:1.7: “Just now, sir, as I was in private retreat this thought came to mind.
snp2.12:1.8: ‘Has my mentor become quenched or not?’”
snp2.12:1.9: Then Venerable Vaṅgīsa got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and addressed him in verse:
snp2.12:2.1: “I ask the teacher unrivaled in wisdom,
snp2.12:2.2: who has cut off all doubts in this very life:
snp2.12:2.3: a monk has died at Āḷavī’s premier shrine,
snp2.12:2.4: who was well-known, famous, and quenched.
snp2.12:3.2: it was given to that brahmin by you, Blessed One.
snp2.12:3.3: He wandered in your honor, yearning for freedom,
snp2.12:3.4: energetic, a resolute Seer of Truth.
snp2.12:4.2: we all wish to know about that disciple.
snp2.12:4.3: Our ears are eager to hear,
snp2.12:4.4: for you are the most excellent teacher.
snp2.12:5.1: Cut off our doubt, declare this to us;
snp2.12:5.2: your wisdom is vast, tell us of his quenching!
snp2.12:5.4: like the thousand-eyed Sakka <j>in the midst of the gods!
snp2.12:6.1: Whatever ties there are, or paths to delusion,
snp2.12:6.2: or things on the side of unknowing, <j>or that are bases of doubt
snp2.12:6.3: vanish on reaching a Realized One,
snp2.12:6.4: for his eye is the best of all people’s.
snp2.12:7.1: If no man were ever to disperse corruptions,
snp2.12:7.2: like the wind dispersing the stormclouds,
snp2.12:7.3: darkness would shroud the whole world;
snp2.12:7.4: not even brilliant men would shine.
snp2.12:8.1: The attentive are bringers of light;
snp2.12:8.2: my hero, that is what I think of you.
snp2.12:8.3: We’ve come for your discernment and knowledge:
snp2.12:8.4: here in this assembly, declare to us about Kappāyana.
snp2.12:9.1: Swiftly send forth your sweet, sweet voice,
snp2.12:9.2: like a goose stretching its neck, gently honking,
snp2.12:9.4: alert, we all listen to you.
snp2.12:10.1: You have entirely abandoned birth and death;
snp2.12:10.2: restrained and pure, I urge you to speak the Dhamma!
snp2.12:10.3: For while ordinary people have no wish-granter,
snp2.12:11.1: Your answer is definitive, and we will adopt it,
snp2.12:11.3: We raise our joined palms one last time,
snp2.12:11.4: one of unrivaled wisdom, <j>don’t deliberately confuse us.
snp2.12:12.1: Knowing the noble teaching from top to bottom,
snp2.12:12.2: unrivaled hero, don’t deliberately confuse us.
snp2.12:12.3: As a man baking in the summer sun <j>would long for water,
snp2.12:12.4: I long for your voice, so let the sound rain  forth.
snp2.12:13.1: Surely Kappāyana did not <j>lead the spiritual life in vain?
snp2.12:13.3: or did he still have a residue?
snp2.12:13.4: Let us hear what kind of liberation he had!”
snp2.12:14.1: “He cut off craving for name and form right here,”
snp2.12:14.3: “the river of darkness that had long lain within him.
snp2.12:14.4: He has entirely crossed over birth and death.”
snp2.12:14.5: So declared the Blessed One, the leader of the five.
snp2.12:15.1: “Now that I have heard your words,
snp2.12:15.2: seventh of seers, I am confident.
snp2.12:15.3: My question, it seems, was not in vain,
snp2.12:15.4: the brahmin did not deceive me.
snp2.12:16.1: As he said, so he did—
snp2.12:16.2: he was a disciple of the Buddha.
snp2.12:16.3: He cut the net of death the deceiver,
snp2.12:17.3: He has indeed gone far beyond
snp2.12:17.4: Death’s dominion so hard to pass.”
